thread.title: TPP: Andrew Robb says deal depends on US
thread.title_full: TPP: Andrew Robb says deal depends on US | afr.com

author: Fiona Buffini
title: TPP: Andrew Robb says deal depends on US
text:
Trade Minister Andrew Robb (left) says: "We have taken decisions provisionally on over 90 per cent of the issues so we are very close and it just needs the movement by the United States on a couple of big issues and we'd be there." Reuters by Fiona Buffini Trade minister Andrew Robb said the prospect of a deal on the regional trade agreement depended on the United States.
Mr Robb admitted that the timing was "getting tight" with an election in Canada in October and the US presidential election ramping up next year.
"We have taken decisions provisionally on over 90 per cent of the issues so we are very close and it just needs the movement by the United States on a couple of big issues and we'd be there."
Pacific trade ministers and business are increasingly split over how to push ahead on the agreement after the failure of talks to close the deal on the weekend .
Talks stalled amid divisions over dairy industry liberalisation, car component export rules and patent protection for a new generation of drugs.
"But I still think there is the opportunity basically because I felt that in the last week, and the week before with the officials, that we made more progress than at any other negotiations that I've been associated with in two years," the minister told the ABC on Monday.
He said "reasonable progress" was made on the issue of biologics where Mr Robb said the US had tried to accommodate Australia's position but the deal was "stymied by problems in two other big areas, cars and dairy".
The minister said Australia had also made "good progress" on the contentious issue of investor state dispute resolution clauses .
 "We were not going to move on that and we wont move on that until such time there are safeguards that give us room to take decisions on public health and the environment that can't be litigated against. We were making good progress on that. That one is close to conclusion I think."
He said the parties had agreed to meet again in a few weeks after talks that he said were "pretty tension packed" with "a lot of anger at times".
"We have agreed within a few weeks to reconvene, we don't like to put a date on it. I am confident in a few weeks we will reconvene and it's a question of how much leg work is done in the interim."
China FTA stalled by 'mischievous' campaign Business Council chief executive Jennifer Westacott said Monday the failure of the TPP reinforced the importance for federal parliament to ratify the China free trade deal, which she said has been attacked by a "mischievous and inaccurate advertising campaign by the unions".
"This is a huge opportunity for Australia, and it is essential it gets passed in the Senate with the safeguards the government has included, and with appropriate transparency and resourcing for compliance and enforcement," Ms Westacott said in a statement.
"It is vital that public debate around the agreement is well informed and not driven by a mischievous and inaccurate advertising campaign by the unions.
"Every week which goes by without this agreement being finalised is a week our competitors will take advantage of."
The BCA encouraged the government to continue its efforts for a deal on the TPP.
"It is important to keep up the momentum for an agreement so the goodwill can be turned into an outcome that benefits all."
